docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to better understand the origins of breast cancer, researchers have begun to look as far back as the womb to identify prenatal factors and childhood experiences, including birth weight, diet and exercise patterns, that may affect a woman's risk of developing breast cancer. Though the data are preliminary, the relationships complex and the conclusions tentative, the emerging findings may help to explain long-suspected influences on breast cancer risk like early puberty, the age of a woman at the end of her first full-term pregnancy and the amount of fat and calories in her diet.

headline.main: Risks For Cancer Can Start In Womb

docs.abstract: Researchers are looking as far back as the womb to identify prenatal factors and childhood experiences, including birth weight, diet and exercise patterns, that may affect woman's risk of developing breast cancer; emerging findings may help to explain long-suspected influences on breast cancer risk like early puberty, age of woman at end of her first full-term pregnancy and amount of fat and calories in her diet (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Terry Hoddinot, 36, of London, Ontario, has been blind since the age of 3. His son, Riley, 3 1/2, lost his left eye a month ago. And the same rare eye cancer, retinoblastoma, was diagnosed in his baby daughter, Katie, while she was still in the womb. But doctors say there is a good chance that they may have saved Katie's vision with a bold new procedure: delivering her prematurely, then treating the affected eye before the cancer had a chance to grow and blind her.

headline.main: Attacking Eye Cancer Early (in the Womb)

docs.abstract: Bold new procedure for attacking retinoblastoma, a rare eye cancer that is diagnosed while child is still in womb, entails delivering baby prematurely, then treating affected eye before cancer has chance to grow and cause blindness; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The day after gunmen mortally wounded his pregnant girlfriend and the police treated him like a suspect, Rae Carruth took shelter at another girlfriend's apartment here and spoke in soft tones on the telephone to his stepfather in California. Carruth's stepfather, Samuel Carruth, had always been the moral compass in his life, helping him successfully navigate the dangerous neighborhood in Sacramento, where he had grown up and where many of his cousins had ended up in jail, friends said.

headline.main: AN ATHLETE ACCUSED: A special report.; Beneath the Smiles, A Tangled Relationship

docs.abstract: Article profiles Carolina Panthers football player Rae Carruth and his tangled relationship with Cherica Adams, who he is acccused of murdering; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans who have complaints about the health care system may soon be in luck -- or maybe not. Many health care professionals expect the medical system in the United States to be overhauled so remarkably during the next two decades that many patients will not be able to recognize it. While such a notion may excite some consumers -- who hasn't fantasized about the death of health maintenance organizations? -- others will no doubt be riled by new procedures that actually provide less medical care and coverage than before.

headline.main: Health Care Consumers Can Expect Change, and a Shock or Two

docs.abstract: Many healh care professionals expect medical system in United States, for better or worse, to be significantly overhauled in next two decades; one of biggest changes is expected to be increasing role of patient in choosing his or her treatment, with consumers relying less on their doctors and more on Internet and prescription-drug advertising campaigns; consolidation is expected to dominate health insurance industry in next 20 years, meaning larger and more powerful helth care organizations and higher prices; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE hands are bigger now, big enough to place gingerly in a slab of wet concrete and leave childish but distinct prints. These children once were so small -- or so sick -- that there was doubt that they would live. Born prematurely or with complications, they received care at the White Plains Hospital neonatal and maternity center here. Now they were back, at a ceremony to mark the very beginning of work on the new state-of-the-art center opening next fall. The wet concrete was only a ceremonial object; the actual building has yet to begin. But the mood was one of celebration and nostalgia as 6-year-old Christopher and Rommel Gramonte, 5-year-old Meagan Barry, 4 1/2-year-old Emon and Eboni Rodney, 4-year-old Amanda Eberle, 3 1/2-year-old Oliver and Sebastian Lane, 3-year-old Parris and Brandon Lloyd and 3-year-old Francisco Jaile-Marti showed the crowd of 100 or so parents, doctors, hospital administrators and supporters that you can be born with big problems and not only survive but thrive.

headline.main: The View From/White Plains; Where the Premature Not Only Survive but Thrive

docs.abstract: White Plains Hospital will open state-of-the-art neonatal and maternity center next fall; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Who was that ghost at the Republican candidates' debate in Iowa on Tuesday? She wandered in and out of the proceedings as the most conservative of the candidates gesticulated wildly at her. Senator Orrin Hatch called her ''pathetic.'' George W. Bush denied that he could see her. The good people of Iowa must have been mighty puzzled. After all, how many of them had even heard of Christine Todd Whitman?

headline.main: Whitman Was at the Debate, And She Didn't Do Too Well

docs.abstract: Iver Peterson On Politics column says New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman has incurred hostility of conservative Republicans, mainly because of her pro-choice stance on abortion, boding poorly for her chance at vice-presidency (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Prof. Donald Fraser Tapley, dean of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons during 10 years of robust growth, died on Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 and lived in Palisades and Hamden, N.Y. The cause was cardiac arrest, the university reported.

headline.main: Donald Tapley, 72; Led Columbia Medical School

docs.abstract: Dr Donald Fraser Tapley, dean of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons from 1973 to 1984, dies at age 72; photo ()

docs.lead_paragraph: Teenage pregnancies are no more unusual in Italy than elsewhere. But the predicament of a 13-year-old retarded girl in Sicily known only as Laura has fascinated the entire country. Today, a judge ruled that Laura's pregnancy should not be ended by abortion. The decision was supposed to remain a secret shared only with Laura's parents and the girl's guardian, but the news quickly leaked out.

headline.main: Abortion Is Rejected for a Girl, 13, Bitterly Dividing the Italians

docs.abstract: Italians are divided over abortion case involving 13-year-old retarded girl; judge rules that Sicilian girl, known only as Laura, should not have her pregnancy ended by abortion; decision was supposed to remain a secret shared only with Laura's parents and girl's guardian, but news quickly leaked out; Rev Oreste Benzi, local priest who led battle to overturn her state-appointed guardian's recommendation for an abortion, is elated by news, calling it 'victory for life'; other Italians, especially those who support abortion rights, view case differently; family identifies father as 14-year-old playmate, who is also retarded (M)
